instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2877: What is 820-2877? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Hi i am practice on an old board a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b, with damage from liquid, the board goes to S0, but no fan spin 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = OK
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = OK
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> = 0K
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = OK
CPUVCORE = 0
ONLY WITH RESET SMC STARTS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Do you really mean SMC reset, or just pressing power button?
Nvidia MCP platform boards don't start without pressing power button, as normal.

Post voltage for L7560, L7620 and L7710.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
you have to excuse me, I meant that if I do the reset procedure the smc starts with the fan at maximum.

L7560 = 0.022
L7620= 1.080
L7710= 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
"starts with the fan at maximum"
Do you mean SMC bypass maybe.
Board doesn't turn on in normal mode?

Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7500</CHIP>; pins 14, 16, 22, 29.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
yes, in fact I said I am a beginner, then these are the measures of u 7500:
14 = 12.55
16 = 5.044
22 = 5.018
29 = 3.303

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message: Post resistance to ground at L7560 (ohm scale).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
016.0 [URL='http://it.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/%CE%A9']Î©[/URL]
Is there low insulation?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message: Where did you find liquid spill?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message: Yes, the part was affected by oxidation

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message: Which areas have been affected by corrosion???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message: Side A from the LVDS connector up to <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> side B smc the circuit of the 3V42 etc. I removed it with some isopropyl alcohol, I rebuilt tracks on <TRANSISTOR>Q5315</TRANSISTOR> and I also replaced it, and it works now I agree on <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> I see if any capacitor pulls down, do you think I have to replace <CHIP>U7500</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Replace <CAPACITOR>C7564</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7565</RESISTOR>; check their traces too.
May need to replace <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>/65; better at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message: I replaced resistance and capacitor but nothing, I did a test with isopropyl alcohol on <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>/65 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7565</TRANSISTOR> heat evaporates fast I'm afraid it pulls down

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
16 ohm doesn't look low for MCP core voltage.
Post resistance to ground at L6995 (ohm scale).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Check all the components related with <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> area.
Pay atention to traces continuity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
I removed the <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> I realized that there is an interruption on pad 14 or the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> pro pad to rebuild it and let's see what happens
But the question that arises is: did it stop by corrosion or why did the U 7500 go short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message: [ATTACH type="full"]60241[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Where did you see short?

Looks like fault caused by corrosion...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage
threads.message: If I hadn't removed the <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> I would never have noticed the interruption, I rebuilt the missing part now it works perfectly. It was very informative. Thank you!
